author: flexman

title: 3D Printed Pinhole 35 mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Appareil photo sténopé à imprimer

Assemblage de onze pièces imprimées en 3D, de quelques vis, d'un morceau de canette de soda et d'une pellicule photo 35 mm, le sténopé 3dPrintedPinhole35mm est extrêmement facile à fabriquer et à utiliser.
Vous trouverez tous les fichiers nécessaires pour avoir le votre !
Pinhole photo camera to print
An assembly of eleven 3D printed pieces, a few screws,  a piece of  a regular  soda can as well as a 35mm photo film. The3dPrintedPinhole 35mm is highly easy to manufacture and use.
You will find all the necessary files to make and have your own !
En français :
Matériel nécessaire :

• Un foret 4 mm et une perceuse
  • Un morceau de papier de verre
  • Un tournevis cruciforme
  • 4 boulons + écrous, têtes 6 pans, 4x40 mm
  • 4 vis autoforantes, cruciformes, 2x12 mm
  • Une aiguille à coudre
  • Une cannette de soda

    Instructions :

  • Imprimez toutes les pièces en PLA noir avec une coque d’une épaisseur de 2 mm minimum et un remplissage de 30%,

    (Boitier, dos, bobine avec support, bouton gauche, bouton droit, 2 languettes, 3 pièces de l’obturateur, clé)

  • Contre-percez les quatre trous de 4 mm de diamètre et insérez les quatre boulons,
  • Poncez les deux trous de manière à y glisser parfaitement les boutons,
  • Glissez les languettes,
  • Fabriquez un trou de 0,25 mm de diamètre (!!!) avec une aiguille dans un morceau d’aluminium d’une cannette de soda, contrôlez à la loupe,
  • Commencez à visser les trois pièces de l’obturateur avec les quatre vis autoforantes,
  • Placez le trou d’aiguille entre l’obturateur et le boitier, et vissez fermement,
  • Fermez le dos de l’appareil,
  • Vissez les écrous avec la clé,

    L’appareil est prêt à recevoir sa première pellicule.

    (voir la notice d'utilisation)

    In English:

    Necessary equipment:

  • a 4 mm drill bit and a drill machine
  • a piece glass paper (or sandpaper)
  • a cross-head screwdriver
  • 4 bolts+ nuts, hex heads, 4x40 mm
  • 4 self-drilling screws, cross-heads, 2x12 mm
  • a sewing needle
  • a soda can

    Instructions :

  • Print all the needed pieces in black PLA with a shell no less than 2mm minimum and a 30% filling,

    (case, back, reel with support, left side button, right side button, 2 strips, 3 parts of the shutter (obturator) , key),

  • Counter-pierce four holes of 4mm diameter and insert the four bolts,
  • Sandpaper both holes in order to perfectly slip the buttons,
  • Slide the strips,
  • Make a 0,25mm diameter hole using a needle on an aluminum piece from a soda can, verify using a magnifying glass,
  • Begin screwing the 3 shutter (obturator) pieces with the four self-drilling screws,
  • Place the needle pierced hole between the shutter (obturator) and the case, and screw firmly,
  • Close the back of the camera,
  • Tighten by screwing the nuts with the key,

    The camera will be ready for its first film.

    (see the user guide)

Based on the excellent work of Thingiverse users whpthomas, emmett, and whosawhatsis, this design incorporates a spring-loaded arm to squeeze the filament between the drive gear and a bearing with a constant amount of pressure. We added improvements to the designs, such as a hole below the drive gear to guide the filament into the hot end. MakerBot Replicator 2 owners will love the ease of this system for keeping filament running smoothly, and we salute the innovative MakerBot users who contributed to this design! UPDATE! The hardware parts for this replacement are available for sale in our online store. Go to http://store.makerbot.com/drive-block-hardware-kit.html. UPDATE! Rev2 files are now uploaded, and there are STEP files for anyone who would like to take a closer look at the design. There is also a version of the Base that can print without support material.

You can find a video of these instructions here: http://youtu.be/ZdOS5NP5eaE As well as the three printed parts, you will need the following: The 2mm and 2.5mm hex wrenches that came with your MakerBot Replicator 2
1 M3 Hex Socket Shoulder Screw, 4mm diameter x 10mm length shoulder
1 Compression Spring, 0.360"OD, 0.276"ID, 0.630" Free Length, 32lbs/in spring rate
1 M3 x 6mm Flat Head Cap Screw
1 Ball Bearing, 4mm ID x 10mm OD x 4mm width
  • Print out SCHDrive.thing. The files are precisely oriented to work well with support material as generated in MakerWare. Use the following settings:
    • Layer height: 0.20 mm
    Infill: 10%
    Shells: 3

  • Remove the support structures from the drive block base and bearing arm.

  • Unload any filament and switch off the MakerBot Replicator 2.

  • Remove the motor wire harness connector from the port at the top of the extruder motor.

  • Use the 2.5 mm hex wrench to loosen the two bolts at the lower corners of the front extruder fan. Pull the bolts, fan guard, fan, spacers and heatsink about a centimeter out of the extruder as one piece. This will free the motor. Pull the motor assembly out of the extruder.

  • Set the motor assembly down on a work surface. Orient it so that the motor shaft points up and the motor connector is on the side farthest from you.

  • Use the 2 mm hex wrench to remove the two bolts holding the drive block to the motor.

  • Remove the drive block. You can put the drive block and bolts aside. You will not need any of these parts to complete this part replacement.

  • Add the new drive block base to the motor so that the flat side rests against the top of the motor, the large hole at the center fits over the drive gear, and the two bolt holes in the base line up with the bolt holes farthest from you on the motor.

  • Add the small flathead screw to the bolt hole on the right of the drive block base. Screw it in using the 2 mm hex wrench.

  • Set the bearing arm down on your work surface with the flattest side facing down. The bearing arm is roughly L-shaped, and on the short side of the L you will see a short post pointing upward. Add the radial bearing to this post.

  • Add the bearing cover to the bearing arm so that the flat side faces up, the more rounded end fits into the round depression at the corner of the bearing arm, and the less rounded end partially covers the bearing. Press the cover on until it is flush with the edges of the bearing arm.

  • Fit one end of the spring over the round bump on the drive block base. The bump protrudes horizontally from the lower right corner of the drive block base.

  • Orient the bearing arm so that the bearing is at the left and the bearing cover faces up. Then line up the corresponding bump on the bearing arm with the other end of the spring.

  • Pinch the front side of the drive block base and the long side of the bearing arm together to compress the spring. Compress the spring until the bolt hole in the bearing arm and the remaining bolt hole in the drive block base line up.

  • Push the shoulder bolt through both bolt holes at the corner of the bearing arm and into the bolt hole on the motor. Use the 2 mm hex wrench to tighten down the bolt. You might have to push down hard on the hex wrench in order to get the shoulder bolt to thread into the hole in the motor.

  • The new drive block is now fully assembled, and you can return the motor assembly to the extruder. Slide the motor assembly back into the extruder.

  • Making sure the fan bolts at the front of the extruder line up with the two lower bolt holes on the extruder motor, tighten the bolts into the motor using the 2.5 mm hex wrench.
    • Note: Make sure you are able to push the bearing arm down. If the bearing arm will not move, the fan bolts are probably too tight.
  • Return the motor wire harness connector to the port at the top of the motor.
    • That's it! Start printing and let us know how it works out!

comments.text: I was getting quite a few extrusion problems with this upgrade. At first I was able to avoid the problem by pausing the print and having the printer "load" a couple inches of filament just before some complex geometry (to push some bubbles out of the nozzle and give the gear a fresh bit of filament to bite into), but I later discovered that there was insufficient force applied to the filament, causing the nozzle to jam and grinding the filament down to a thickness that the gear couldn't grip onto.

comments.author: lewing

comments.text:
I printed this something last year and have only had a small handful of prints where it has stopped extruding, the last of which was a month or two ago. This, combined with a leveling calibration print and a dial indicator mount have given me the reliable repeatability I had expected when I bought my Replicator 2.
Thank you for designing this and putting it out there for all of us to use!
comments.author: CosworthTC

comments.text:
I have tried this upgrade multiple times and I can't seem to get good prints from it.
I have assembled the upgrade using the kit bought directly from Makerbot, and I have ensured I have printed and assembled the parts properly. Basically, when I print, or even just use the load filament utility on my replicator 2 the filament doesn't extrude as fast as it should. If I was to compare the upgrade to the original grub screw drive block, I would say the stream coming out is half the speed of the grub screw drive block. I am pretty sure this is due to insufficient force being applied to the filament.
Can anyone help me with this problem as I have had to resort to using the grub screw which has been working but occasionally results in the clicking problem resulting in failed prints.
comments.author: DepthDesign3D

comments.text: I had a similar problem and discovered that the set screw was loose on the grub screw. Loosened it, aligned it with the flat side of the shaft on the stepper, and re-tightened, and that fixed my filament "drive" issues. After disassembling I discovered that the lever arm was rubbing against the place where the grub/set screw was on the notched wheel. comments.text: Hi All. Im just going to add my 2 cents worth. I could not print at all with my Rep2 when I first got it. Bilby in Australia eventually printed me a WHPThomas version of this and I have had no Problems with filament since, Except for the clear filament that came with the unit from makerbot. It jams in the extruder for no reason and blocks up after about an hour. After some research and measuring I found 2 things. 1 The filament varied from 1.7mm to 1.9mm in different areas and through this didn't jam in the feeder is jammed in the heat pipe. 2 I found out through the supplier that the filament from Makerbot has issues with moisture. I cant remember the exact story but the explanation went along the lines of dont use the supplied filament. I havent used it and have had no failed prints due to filament. Granted I have had plenty of bad prints but most are now due to me being slack in the setup. In regards to Emmets prints i have done many and they have worked out perfect. I agree that if you want print his objects, you need to do a proper setup and read his instructions. In regards to Maker bot I think that they should be sending every Rep2 owner the updated feeder for free. You have made a good product but you are now subjecting it bad publicity simply because you are not supporting your users. Its obvious that the feeder is useless and needs to be replaced. On a final note I love my printer and couldnt imagine life with out it.

comments.text: One other point/question for Makerbot.  It appears that the settings in the original Makerbot slicer profiles were tweaked to compensate for the original plunger design. Have you worked out replacement profiles that work better with the new extruder design?
comments.author: elgullitch

comments.text: There's nothing about this design that would require a different profile - the diameter of the gear didn't change, just the mechanism for pressing filament against the gear.
comments.author: elgullitch

comments.text:
True, the gear didn't change. However, a flat delrin plunger tensioned by a screw and o-ring will not give consistent positive engagement with the drive gear in the same manner that a spring loaded bearing does. If you dig into the default profiles that shipped with the Makerbot, it appears that they fudged the filament size and multiplier to compensate for slippage in the drive mechanism.
Look at it this way - if the original mechanism worked reliably, this upgrade wouldn't offer any noticeable improvements in performance.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: The plunger and spring tensioned design have the same geometry and profile because the gear is the same. The plunger behaves the same as the spring tension when adjusted to proper pressure on consistently sized filament, with no slipping, etc. The advantage of the spring tensioned design is that it deals better with variable sized filament, and that you can manually release pressure for loading and unloading filament. But same gear = same profile.
comments.author: elgullitch

Yes, they are acknowledging that the original design is inferior.  Yes, they are charging a few bucks for the parts kit (BTW, I paid almost $8 just for the bearing I used)   But in the grand scheme of things, this is how an innovative company who supports an innovative community should work.

comments.text: I disagree with your position.  Did your automobile come with an "experimental" warranty?  Fortunately for me (at least), I have a CNC mill and was able to machine a solution that is similar to yours out of aluminum.  The major difference between the various designs here (including yours) and mine is that mine was made out of aluminum and in addition has an adjustment screw through the compression spring to facilitate "pre-load" (e.g. as in a motorcycle shock absorber).   For me to have to design such a fix is minimal since I observed the problem, had the machinery to fix it, and was able to do so, even though it was a major inconvenience and as well as a major let down.  For almost everyone else, being sold a 3d printer as "expertly designed" (I believe you referenced as such in your PLA solution), what can be said other than they are left with a machine that was not indeed "expertly designed". description.text:
Heyo all! Here is a very fine set of Tokens for Malifaux. Although they're designed with that game in mind, I think they'll do great for any other weird west or terror game around.  They are free for personal use, of course.
If you like the projects on my Thingiverse, consider giving a tip. Not only I will appreciate it immensely, I promise to put it to good use. Thanks for your consideration!

Based on the classic wall mounted extended shaving mirror. I had a broken halogen lamp which i thought i could recycle and here is what i came up with, update to follow
I will provide a OpenScad File for the End piece so you can put what ever you like at the end. I have to just to say this was my first project i designed and printed and so my prints are not perfect. Doing this thing helped me get my bearings around my printer and understand some of its quirks.

For each X in the extender you need 2 (Double_length.stl) plate and (Single_length.stl). I needed only 2 but you can do as many as you want. The wall mount has 2 options. use the fixed holder (top_wall_bracket_slider_V3.stl) for perpendicular action only or the (top_wall_bracket_slider_V2.stl) with (top_wall_bracket_V2.stl) for full 180 deg movement You need 1(slider.stl) and 1 (bottom_wall_clamp.stl) For the end section use 1 (single_lamp_end.stl) and 1 each of (right_lamp_strut.stl) and (left_lamp_strut.stl). The Lamp_End.stl will hold a 13mm diameter tube which is my broken lamp part. Use the (cable_holder.stl) to string a cable along the extender to the lamp end. Vitamins

This is Threaded Filament Dust Filter - Replicator 1,2 & 2X by ppyromann with instructions to make a filament colorizer.

Print the filter, put in a sponge (I used a wedge shaped makeup sponge cause that's what I had laying around), fill with alcohol based ink. I got the alcohol based ink from Dick Blick http://www.dickblick.com/products/spectrum-noir-marker-ink-refills/ .
You can make your own colors if you get the three primary colors (red, blue, yellow) and mix them, plus black.
Assemble the filter but don't screw it together, put the filament and sponge in the filter, fill it up with ink, and screw it together.
I needed to ream out the barrel a little because the hole was pretty tight and pulled the ink back off the filament. When I reamed it out so there was a little extra room, the ink stayed on the filament.
Note: the print file is not changed at all from ppyromann's file. All of the credit for the design of the original filter goes to ppyromann. I just get the credit for the alcohol ink idea, which is based on all of the ink colorizers using Sharpies.

author: OutstandingRice

description.text:
Have you got some 15mm pipes running vertically anywhere that would be nice to hang coats (or anything) on ? Like next to your front door perhaps ? Well I have. and since deciding to make these I noticed a fair few other uk houses do too. May also be found in airing cupboards. I have now tested these on hot pipes and although they stay in place on their own in my case they couldn't hold a coat. They may well hold something lighter I didn't try. Print in abs if you want to use them on a hot pipe. Printed in PLA the shrinkage makes these a very tight fit, ABS shrinks less so may be a bit loose to hold anything heavy.
As you can tell this was thrown together EXTREMELY quickly to show somebody how easy tinkercad is, however the printed item works very well and looks nice and subtle.
From "hey shall I make one of these", the design and the actual printing it was clipped on the pipe in an hour and saving my bike from getting covered with one of my coats. So technically these things are a keep fit device.
I can make a tighter one or perhaps 22mm if required. I could also redesign for horizontal pipes, they seem secure enough to not rotate, unless you want it for your suit of armour. You can ask me to make a multi hook version but I suspect my response will be "just print more than one".
I printed with 3 shells, 15% infill PLA, it took about 30 minutes.

title: Case for 1/3 inch Sony CCD camera

description.text:
This case is for the Sony 1/3 inch open PCB camera. It covers the entire front, and snaps in place. There are two versions, a curved and a compact one. There is also a version with an extended skirt that also protects the rear PCB when it is mounted on a flat surface with suitably sized spacers.   
The image shows the compact one with skirt, mounted on a simple pan/tilt device.  
The OpenSCAD file should allow easy tuning of most parameters.

The curved versions builds from the bottom, and can be tricky to get to build nicely without supports. The more compact version builds from the top, and should build without much problems.
The extra edge along the bottom of the rounded case is to make it stick better: it can be cut off after printing.

title: Bike Seat Rail Mount - Topeak F25

description.text:
The Topeak F25 seat rail clamp does a great job of mounting a pack to the bottom of your bike seat. However, I wanted to mount other things (batteries, lights, etc.) to my seat, and used this clamp as a platform upon which I could design other mounts. It locks directly onto the Topeak F25 rail clamp and unlocks easily with the tab.
This model is designed to match the Topeak F25 (http://www.amazon.com/Topeak-F25-Wedge-Pack-Fixer/dp/B005DTILE0).
OpenSCad and stl files are both supplied. Comment below if you want a variation of some sort!

Simply combine this with the top of your model (OpenSCad and stl files are both available) and you'll be ready to mount your new part onto your Topeak F25 Seat rail clamp.
This will require some minimal supports on the overhang.

comments.author: se7en

description.text:
This is a revival of an old Physics favorite: The air puck.  These used to be driven by CO2 in a metal framework.  Unfortunately the plastic is too insullating.  This uses a balloon and a disused CD-DVD.  Build this on a carefully leveled and tightened extruder (to insure circularity) and you have nearly fricitonless air puck.  
There is a problem with the nozzle. An inverted rectangle causes it to be closed off.  Look for v2.0 of this 'thing' for the fix.

Some assembly required.  The small pins sit in the 4 holes around the 'base'.  The base fits into the hole of a standard CD.  The four 'wings' are designed to hold standard physics test masses to change the overall mass of the puck.  The nozzle sits on top and requires a balloon.  I use 5 min epoxy to glue it together but cyanoacrylate glues should work as well.  I have the best results if I attach everything to the 'read' side.  The label side is usually the smoothest side and is best placed face down.  The 'cone' is used to make sure large balloons don't flop over and slow down the motion.  The results are remarkably consistent.

comments.text: There is a small problem with the nozzle in v1.0 which isn't apparent until you print it. There is an inverted rectangle that causes the opening through the center to close off. (A simple work around is to drill a hole through it. It is thin.)  I have uploaded this new version of the .thing file which fixes the issue.  The round bumper could be made out of some rubbery material like ninja flex to create a set of 'bumper' pucks.  I am experimenting with this idea at present. I'll upload images of the final puck soon.  Inflating the balloon can be a bit of a pain but I picked an old 12V air pump out of the trash which I have resurrected to help inflate a classroom full of these things.

If you need to mount the speaker on something, there are M5 mounting holes at the tips of the legs.

This wheel is the official 3D printed wheel for the X-Derby. Feel free to download and print for the Official race. We recommend PLA, but ABS works too.
.3 mm Z
100% fill
What is the X-Derby?
Think Boy Scout Pinewood Derby with minimal rules.
The track is larger and undulating. Few restrictions on size or materials that you can use to build your car. Prizes for fastest car and most creative plus many more. Have fun, being creative and innovative in materials and designs and learn some engineering techniques along the way.
Don't have a 3D printer? Get it printed locally here; http://www.3dhubs.com/bend/hubs/hdmm

The model was created in Autodesk Fusion360.
The hub was designed to use 16 gauge nails 1.25" long as axles.
There is also a guide that can be printed to help make holes for the nails.
To drill the holes cut the head off of a 16 gauge nail and chuck it up in an electric drill. Make sure that you do not drill the full 1.25" depth so the axle nail will seat firmly.
For more information please visit
http://www.makermill.org

So I found out that the knob that was on the upstairs bathroom had the wrong one installed and was stripped out so I took it and took many measurements with my digital calipers. I added my own twist to it and printed it out. Accidentally snapped off the internal shaft when removing support material but heated a nail and welded it back together. I used glow-in-the-dark PLA for it which isn't as strong as regular PLA. It's installed and works great. It takes a #10-24x1-1/4. It doesn't work for sink faucets. They could with some slight modification though. It isn't exactly how I want it to look, but it's functional and not too shabby if I do say so myself.

author: cowboysfan69812

title: iStation (Apple charging station for 2 iPads & 2 iPhones)

description.text: We had a real problem with clutter near the outlet used for charging 2 iPads and 2 iPhones.  The iStation is capable of cradling/charging all of our devices by using the original Apple charging cables.  Both the iPhone and iPad connector ports may be swapped for the lightning or 30-pin charging cable.  Although I intended all 4 devices to be placed in vertically, we have opted to place the iPads in more of a filing format with the cables plugged in from the side.

• Obtain the following hardware:
    • M3 machine screws (8 total; >=10mm)
    • M3 nuts (8 total)
    • M3 machine screw (1 total; >35mm)
  • Print the base station unit (2 shells; 25% infill; PLA; 0.25mm height)
  • Print 4 desired connectors (2 shells; 25% infill; PLA; 0.25mm height)
  • Using a 35mm or longer M3 screw, pull the M3 nuts into the bottom cutouts from above the charging port in order to capture the nuts in place
  • Affix charging cables to the respective connectors
  • Mount the connectors into place with 10mm M3 screws
  • Snake cables through traces in the underside of the iStation
  • Place tape (masking or packaging) on the underside of the station to keep the cables in place.
  • Slide your devices into place and start charging while also getting a bit more organized

Rather than build Lego structures and things on a big flat plate, I thought it would be fun to create a more interesting terrain. I combined a number of Parametric Lego modules built in OpenSCAD with an organic surface in Fusion 360. The result was a group of nine modules that can be connected with Lego pieces to make any number of different models. The scale can be changed so this represents an entire city or just one building on stilts over a lake. The modules can be painted so they are more realistic. In the example, I used pieces from the Lego Architecture Studio to make nine separate abstract designs.

Designed in OpenSCAD and Fusion 360, sliced in Simplify3D, and printed on a MakerBot Replicator2 with Elmer's Craft Bond glue stick on a glass build plate with MakerBot and PushPlastic filament with the following settings:
Infill = 20%
Layer height = 0.2
No. shells = 4
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220C

title: Flashforge cooling duct adapter plate 2x 40mm fans
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
We recently got a Flashforge Creator Pro at the office, and while we were trying to get it working well with PLA, we stumbled across this.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:448793
Seems like a great design!
We didn't have a 60mm fan, and being too impatient to wait for 2 day shipping, I made this adapter plate. It converts the design to work with dual 40mm fans. You just need some small wood screws and those typical short fan screws and you're all set.
The adapter plate is designed so the screws holding the fans on will be countersunk. This ensures a good flush fit onto the cooling duct to minimize air leakage.
The design is available in two thicknesses. The thin file is 2.5mm and the other is 5mm thick.
We found when using a 20mm thick fan, go with the thin plate to avoid minor crashes. We're always excited to hear feedback, so please leave us comments to tell us what you think!

title: My Old Replicator 2 Power Brick Holder - Check out 82565 instead

description.text:
I don't use this thing any more. I have a better, much more stable design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82565 I'm only leaving this up on Thingiverse in the event someone wants to derive something else from it.... New version 3/11/13 Better grip on power brick and SNUG fit to the Rep 2. I hate power bricks almost as much as I hate wallwartsâ€¦ Our Rep2 lives on a mobile cart so the power brick can't live unobtrusively under a desk (keeping the dust bunnies warm). After having the brick get jostled and unplugged in the middle of a build for the third time, I came up with this idea. Is it a long term solution? I donâ€™t know, but Iâ€™m trying it for now. At least it puts the brick in what is currently unused space on the back of the single extruder Replicator 2. Underneath the brick cradle is a cable management clip.
Undoubtedly I spent way too much time and filament on a problem better solved with duct tape and velcro...... Updated 2/25/2013 to increase the clip angle. Better gripping of the power brick.

Printed from Makerware using the high resolution profile, but with these settings:
Infill: 25%
Shells: 3
Layer: 0.3mm
Extrude: 80 mm/sec
Travel: 150 mm/sec
I added Ear Rafts http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38272 at all the corners in Makerware to ensure bonding. You could also use a raft but I prefer whpthomas' approach.
The Makerbot logo serves as a pressure pad to hold the brick more securely. The oval cutouts are just to reduce filament usage -- This material would contribute little to structural strength. Modeled in Alibre Design - source included. Please post all modified source.

author: nursenee

title: Platform, Mini Lift, MG90S Micro Servo

description.text:
Messing around with the tank and made this little mini lift. All I could think of was how cool this would be to use with Hot Wheels or Matchbox cars. Uses #4x1/4" and #4x3/8" sheet metal screws and #15 brad nails to put together. Platform is 2" x 2 7/8" and everything fits under it when lifted. Platform moves .300" (top of platform) to 2.200" fully lifted. Uses MG90S Tower Pro Servo. Has a servo adjuster to get the right gear mess. Quick build, but lots of filing and fitting. Have fun!
Here is a video of it working https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aSNia01SjYs

Arm and platform need support. Drill all of the #4 screw holes to .089-.093" for thread and .120" to go through part. For #15 brad nails cut to length with dikes and file any sharp edges on cut. Drill brad nail holes to .073" on the base and platform and .076" on the arms, so the arms turn on the nail. Clearances are close on brad nails under platform, cut as short as you can but still have a little to slide the nail out enough to grab with pliers to pull out.
On the gear lift arm, file the shaft down smooth and round. Assemble arm caps with #4x3/8" screws and drill out base and caps to fit for gear lift arm. Mine needed drilled out with .182" bit for the lift arm to turn smooth. You can file down the ridge in hole to help snap the lift arm in base.
The servo is adjustable so you can adjust how the gears match up. Took a couple gear prints to get a good gear and lift arm. You can time the gear it is a 12 tooth so every 3rd gear tooth is the same on the splines of servo. You can turn the gear to get the right throw of the arm and good teeth on the gear. Drill out the servo gear to .180" and push on the servo to cut splines in gear. The gear is really hard to push on and helps to push with servo on gear on a flat surface. File down the gear to fit so it doesn't hit arm if needed.
You may need to file down the ends of the arms in platform or Dremel tool out the sockets in the platform for arms to fit.
The more time you take fitting the better it will work.
I had a couple 9 volt batteries on the lift so it is pretty powerful for its size.
Lift goes from .3" to 2.2", top of platform. Platform is 2" x 2 7/8" on top. Mounts with two screw tabs in base and one in the thin part of base by arm.

I need to crush three pills every morning and designed this pair for the job. Three fairly small pills which I do in one go.
Designed in MOI.
Made on a Robox in Robox ABS. (As you can see I've not yet mastered the art of a good surface finish).
Although I've made these in ABS I recommend using PLA as it is a harder material and, I think, more suitable for this application.
Having used this for a while I have some recommendations on how to best use it:
  • Press down hard to break the pills into smaller pieces.
  • Then while rocking the pestle forwards and backwards, rotate the mortar.
    Works surprisingly effectively - or so it seems to me!
    • After some weeks using this I concluded that the pestle could be a little taller and that more clearance between the sides of the mortar and the pestle would give more room for the 'pill powder'. The updated design is pestle 01.stl.

The distance between the deepest part of the mortar (the bowl) and the underside of the base is 3.2mm so I suggest that you set your wall section top and bottom at 1.6mm - and hence use a 0.2mm layer height.
I used the same settings for the pestle.

These files are for Seimitsu Buttons to allow them to use snap action microswitches instead of the standard PS-14-G microswitch. Now you can use Cherry, Zippy, or Omron switches with any Seimitsu PS-14-G or KN button for tactile feedback and a clicky button!
*Note the later pictures show a screw and nut to hold the switch together. That is a prototype model and will not be needed for the actual assembly.

Each side is appropriately named for its purpose. When assembling begin by mounting the microswitch on either of the sides tabs, then assemble the remaining side by fitting the tabs into the microswitches mounting holes.
Make sure the microswitch plunger pin is facing up between the two walls of the assembly.
before installing the assembly in the button, mount your button in whatever panel or arcade controller you choose to use. We will be mounting one your button is secured.
Insert the plunger pin first into the button within the button plungers slot.
Insert your switch assembly by pinching the top of the assembly near the two extrusions and make sure that the assembly is firmly seated on the plunger rim. One extrusion should mount above the rim, another below.
Wire your button and enjoy!

This is a piggy bank in the shape of the red angry bird as dictated by my 7 year old. It's designed to be printed in four colors: red, white, black and gold to match the character. It has a (crude) plug in the bottom that you can screw in and out for the money to be released. The slot at the top is designed for quarters but if you want to use if for other currencies for larger coins you could just scale it a bit. An English 2 Pence piece almost fits as it is.

This is In 5 parts. The belly is white and has the plug to the side. I printed this on rep G with outside supports which seemed to work fine. You might be able to get away without supports. The other white piece is the eyes which print very quickly. They're not quite flat so I would print with a raft and support as well as they clean up very easily. I used 100% fill just to be sure as they're so tiny. The main hull is the Red part which prints fine without raft or supports on mine. You get a few stray wisps on the inside but it cleans up well. I printed with 15 % flll to keep it strong. Then there's the beak which I printed in gold (yellow would do). I suspect this will print fine without support. I did print with supports but it didn't need much cleaning. Then there's a final black parts section which is the eyebrows and tail. Print solid with a raft as the eyebrows are at an angle. I just glued the pieces together with gorilla glue and all was good. I printed this on my rep2 using slic3r and whpthomas' 100 micron profile http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39050.

description.text:
Small box for carrying an Arduino plus a shield. The bottom of the box has a swivel piece to lock it in place. 
Nothing fancy but it did come out well and can be used as a starting point for other projects. 
Missing from the pictures are the standoffs for the Arduino. I'm going to use eight little circles with a hole in the middle and build up four little stands. Same technique as the bottom feet.

The material is 3mm birch. An 8.5 x 11 inch piece should do fine.
There are eight little squares which are used to build up feet for the bottom piece. When gluing the feet make sure to get the pieces square and flush or bottom will bind and make it hard to open and close. If that happens just file edges a little until to fits without binding. 
Use white glue for the seams since it sands easily. 
The box was finished off with two coats of Minwax clear stain.

title: Robo3D Z-Axis Auto-Level Nut Adapter - 11mm Wrench to 13mm Wrench

description.text:
Quick note, the strange bridges seen in the center cutout sections shouldn't be there, but they also do not print out, so not a problem. Seems to be some error in reading the .obj file, assuming something to do with the boolean used in 3ds max for cutout
This is a small cap for the couplers used in Mike Kelly's Robo3D Auto-Level Mod (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:349935).
I had issues where the only coupler I could find to fit my 5/16 threaded rod had outer dimensions to fit an 11mm wrench, and the Robo3D uses a 5/16 nut that fits a 13mm wrench.
Originally, I tried just recreating the entire mount to include the cap, not thinking that this design would eliminate my ability to adjust the height of the micro-switch. Obviously, that didn't work. So I cut the cap off of one of them and tried it. Worked great.
So I ended up just seperating the cap from the model and printing them out as such. Used these settings:
PLA
Layer Height: .1976mm (due to imperial rod error, fixes step problem, equates to .2mm layer height, but the lower of the two options. The option is .2046, but I find the layers are more likely to separate on thinner pieces at this setting, so I use the closest even step under the layer height I want.)
Fill Density: 100%
Print Speed: 10mm/s
Brim
Have not tried these out yet, but seem to be a perfect fit. For long term use, it may be better to use a different material than PLA, but I haven't worked with any others yet, and am just about to move into ABS once my ventilation gets installed. If anyone knows the best material to use for longevity, please let me know in the comments.

Miniature hand drill. I was in desperate need of a small chuck/hand drill to hold onto some 0.6/0.8/1.0mm drill bits to clean out some holes but couldn't find a place the sold them for a decent price. Holding and placing such small drill bits was a pain, so I quickly modeled and printed this as an emergency/temporary measure. Works well enough but lots of areas that can be improved. Might make this parametric later... http://www.madox.net/

FDM Printers (Up!, MakerBot etc) : The drill bit holder needs to be printed 'FLAT', otherwise the piece may be too fragile and break as the prongs are bend together.  The layer boundaries are weak and may shear through if printed 'TALL' on a FDM printer.
The other two pieces are printed tall.  The support structures for the threads are easily removed by simply removing other attached support structures and unscrewing.
The pieces feature a M10 thread, so 0.2mm and fine settings are recommended.
//Tested on an Up!.  Not tested on a MakerBot, volunteers welcome!

title: Brushless Motor Thrust Bench Jig Parts

description.text:
I made a bench testing jig for brushless motors out of what I had laying around: 16mm aluminum square tube, 1/4" jig hardware, and rivets. And it worked great, but then I got a 3D printer and made some improvements.
Here's the files. Update: wow this is old and nasty. I made three other versions after this. I don't recommend that you use this design as a hot motor will melt the plastic.

I'll get around to this when all the parts are dialed in. The finished jig will use bearings and cost less than $30.
You can get the scale from Harbor Freight - ~$13
I'm not sure where I found those little quick disconnect joints but those are essential to this system.
It should be obvious that the prop is installed as a tractor facing inward and the most dangerous place to be is in line with that prop (should it split).

WORLD HERITAGE RICE MOLD PROJECT No.1 Mt.FUJI RICE MOLD
  • Print out Mt.Fuji with a 3D printer...and take a minute to admire its beauty!
  • LIghtly wet the mold and fill it with freshly made short-grain rice.
  • Flip over the mold and place the mountain of rice on a dish.
  • Add curry to the rice. Planting broccoli tress is optional ;)
  • Mt. Fuji curry is ready to be served!
    Let’s make world heritages out of rice!
    Anyone can join this project. By downloading and printing the 3D data, you can create a mold to form rice into famous locations. Please enjoy/show off your local world heritage sites by creating its mold data and uploading it. Also, feel free to fill your mold with whatever ingredients you like.
    • The first installment for this project is Japan’s one and only Mt. Fuji mold!
    Adjust the amount of a single serving of rice by changing the size of the mold.
    I hope that this will make your meal more enjoyable! FabLab Kamakura
    Made by coma.
